This may Suffice concerning the constituc[i]on of Natura[l]
bodyes on which their colours depend. But for further under 
standing the Nature of reflexions, I shall add these two 
following Propositions 
Prop: 8. The cause of the reflexion is not the impinging 
of Light on the Solid & impervious parts of bodies, as is 
commonly Supposed.
This will appear by the following considerac[i]ons: first 
that in the passage of Light out of Glasse into Air there is a 
reflexion as Strong or Stronger then in its passage out of Air 
into Glasse, and by many degrees Stronger then in its passage 
out of Glasse into water. And it seemes not probable, that 
Air Should haue more reflecting parts then water or Glasse.
But if that Should possibly be Supposed, it will availe nothing 
for the reflexion is as Strong, if not Stronger, when the Air 
is drawne away from the Glasse, (Suppose in the Air 
Pump invented by Mr. Boyle) as when it is adjacent to it.
Secondly if Light in its passage out of Glasse into Air be 
incident more obliquely then at an angle of 40 or 41 degrees 
it is wholly <u>reflected <\u>: if lesse obliquely, it is in great 
measure <u>transmitted<\u>. Now it is not to be imagined that 
Light, at one degree of Obliquity Should meet with pores 
enough in the Aire to transmit the greater part of it, & at 
another degree of Obliquity meet with nothing but parts to 
reflect it wholly, especially considering that in its passage 
out of Air into Glasse how oblique soeuer be its incidence,
it finds pores enough in the Glasse to transmitt the greatest 
part of it. If any man suppose, that it is not reflected by the 
Air but by the utmost Sup[er]ficiall parts of the glasse, there is 
Still the Same difficulty, besides that Such a Supposic[i]on is 
unintelligible, & will also appear to be false by applying water
